Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: InvertNet--An Integrative Platform for Research on Environmental Change, Species Discovery and Identification
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create InvertNet, an on-line virtual museum comprising >50 million insect and related arthropod specimens housed at 22 Midwestern institutions, focusing on the research theme of effects of land use changes on the biota of the Great Lakes and upper Mississippi River drainage basins. These collections document 160 years of environmental change and are an invaluable and irreplaceable resource but, at present, are largely inaccessible to scientists and the general public. Most previous efforts to capture and disseminate invertebrate collection data have focused on label data alone. InvertNet will use advanced digitization and networking technologies to capture and display 2D and 3D images of specimens and labels, and incorporate them into a searchable database. These new techniques should reduce the cost of digitizing insect specimens substantially.

By allowing users to find and view detailed images of specimens of particular species and their associated data labels, InvertNet will provide universal access to collections previously restricted to researchers. It will include links to the popular BugGuide.net insect identification website and to other biodiversity data portals used by researchers, educators, and the general public. This will facilitate and support many aspects of biological research and education, including species discovery and identification, pest management, ecology and biogeography. InvertNet will serve as a model, applicable to other kinds of biological collections, for the use of efficient, computer-assisted procedures to increase the speed and accuracy of collection data capture. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Severin-McDaniel Insect Research Collection collaboration with the InvertNet Project occurred from 2012-2015. The project was successful in basic data capture of nearly 209,000 specimen records from the collection representing an estimated 30% of the collection holdings of most taxonomic groups of insects, and the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

The project supported completely one graduate student who functioned as the collection manager and oversaw the daily operations of the project. This student also completed her PhD in association with the project. Three additional graduate students participated in aspects of the project that affected their research topics, and each has completed their programs and moved on to employment or further studies. Seven undergraduate students worked during various periods as hourly employees on the project and completed their studies in coordination with the ending of the subaward. One of the students spent 2.5 years with the project and used the curatorial and databasing skills gained in her subsequent employment. Under-represented groups were included in the project. Graduate students were 75% female, while undergraduate students were 35% female. Women had the longest employment periods. International students comprised 36% of all students associated with the project.

No fewer than 34 peer-reviewed publications were completed during the course of the project, with at least another 5 remaining in preparation. Ten of these publications had project associated graduate students as lead or other coauthor status. One undergraduate was a lead author on one paper. Coauthors of all articles represented 15 institutions in four countries other than the U.S.A., and federal, state, university, and private individuals. An additional eight abstracts and non-peer review articles were also published, and seven posters and seven oral presentations were given at national meetings regarding topics associated with the project.

Lack of subsequent funding from home institution or other alternative sources, the departure of project personnel deeply familiar with the robot and associated systems severely restricted progress on database contribution and imaging. Programming and operational issues with the imaging robot prevented acquisition of planned imaging to the end of the extension period. Collated data in spreadsheet form was submitted to Specify, but not made available online due to server restrictions at the home institutions. Data was and continues to be submitted to the National Science Foundation supported Integrated Digitized Biocollections project in Gainesville, Florida, for further submission to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility based in Copenhagen, Denmark.

The project provided the employment and training of seven undergraduate hourly workers and professional training for Masters of Science (3) and Doctorate of Philosophy (1) students. All students involved with the project graduated and moved into further educational opportunities or professional jobs. Activities of the project increased the on campus exposure of the Severin-McDaniel Insect Research Collection to undergraduates interested in insect taxonomy and natural history, and contributed to the development of a native bee-focused pollinator inventory project with Indigenous American undergraduate students at the Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation funded by the USDA-NIFA.

Additional spinoffs from the project continue to be generated, including the attaction of new undergraduate research projects and new funding for taxon directed investigations especially with regard to pollinators in the northern Great Plains region.
